question: What is the primary purpose of SysML as described in the specification?
options: A. Modeling software systems only
B. Facilitating a model-based systems engineering approach
C. Serving as a general-purpose programming language
D. Documenting business processes only
E. Providing a platform for simulation only

question: Which of the following are true about SysML namespaces?
options: A. Namespaces can only contain packages
B. Namespaces can provide names for contained elements
C. An element can have multiple memberships in namespaces
D. Namespaces cannot be nested
E. Namespace membership can define visibility

question: Which statements about SysML dependencies are correct?
options: A. Dependencies are always binary
B. Dependencies may involve any number of client and supplier elements
C. The direction of dependency is always from supplier to client
D. Dependencies can represent refinement relationships
E. Dependencies cannot be annotated

question: Which of the following is NOT a valid concrete syntax conformance for SysML tools?
options: A. Textual notation conformance
B. Graphical notation conformance
C. Semantic conformance
D. Model interchange conformance
E. Physical device conformance

question: What is true about SysML elements and their identifiers?
options: A. Every element has a unique element ID
B. An element’s element ID can change over time
C. Elements can have alias IDs
D. Only root elements have IDs
E. Element IDs are specified in textual notation

question: In SysML, what is a package?
options: A. A type of attribute
B. A kind of namespace used to organize models
C. A required element for every model
D. A graphical-only construct
E. A language keyword only for legacy support

question: How can comments be attached to elements in SysML textual notation?
options: A. Using the keyword `comment` followed by `about` and the element name(s)
B. By using single-line `//` comments
C. Only in graphical diagrams
D. By writing text after the element name
E. Comments cannot be attached in textual notation

question: Which statements about annotations in SysML are true?
options: A. Annotations are always about packages
B. Documentation is a special kind of comment
C. Textual representations can be in languages other than SysML
D. Only one annotation can exist per element
E. Annotations must be graphical

question: What are possible visibilities for memberships in a namespace?
options: A. public
B. internal
C. protected
D. package
E. private

question: What is required for a SysML tool to claim full conformance?
options: A. Support for Abstract Syntax Conformance
B. Model Interchange Conformance
C. Concrete Syntax Conformance
D. Domain Library Support
E. Semantic Conformance

question: Which of the following are correct about part definitions and usages in SysML?
options: A. A part usage must be defined by a part definition
B. Part usages can exist without definitions
C. Part definitions and usages are both namespaces
D. Part usages can specialize their definition for context
E. Part usages cannot be owned by namespaces

question: How can an alias be declared in a package?
options: A. With the `alias` keyword, an alias name, and a `for` clause referencing the target element
B. Using the `public` keyword
C. With an `import` statement
D. By direct assignment
E. By using a comment

question: In SysML, which are the correct ways to represent an element’s name?
options: A. As a basic name, starting with a letter or underscore
B. As an unrestricted name in single quotes
C. Only in camelCase
D. Only in ALLCAPS
E. With spaces, using unrestricted names

question: What is true about import relationships in SysML?
options: A. They allow elements from another namespace to be referenced
B. Imports may be recursive
C. Imported members become unowned members in the importing namespace
D. Imports can filter based on metadata
E. Imports must be private

question: Which are valid standard language names for textual representations in SysML?
options: A. "sysml"
B. "uml"
C. "ocl"
D. "alf"
E. "kerml"

question: Which of the following statements about relationship deletion rules are correct?
options: A. Deleting a root element deletes all elements in its ownership tree
B. Deleting an owned element may trigger cascading deletions
C. Deleting an element always deletes its owner
D. Only direct owned elements are deleted
E. An element can have multiple owners

question: In SysML, what is the meaning of a documentation comment?
options: A. It is a comment used only for graphical notation
B. It is a special kind of comment always annotating its owning element
C. It cannot be owned by a namespace
D. It is only used in packages
E. It always requires an `about` clause

question: What is true about qualified names in SysML?
options: A. They resolve elements in the context of nested namespaces
B. Qualified names use `::` as separators
C. Name resolution is defined by KerML
D. Qualified names appear in abstract syntax
E. Unqualified names can be ambiguous

question: Which of the following are modeling constructs specific to SysML (beyond KerML)?
options: A. Attributes
B. Ports
C. Parts
D. Actions
E. States

question: Which are correct statements about element ownership in SysML?
options: A. A namespace may own multiple elements
B. Ownership implies cascading deletions
C. Non-owning memberships can provide alias names
D. Ownership is shown in the graphical notation
E. Elements can be owned by more than one namespace

question: Which of the following best describes a relationship in SysML?
options: A. An element relating two or more elements
B. Always a graphical connector
C. Never directed
D. Cannot own other elements
E. Only used in behavioral diagrams

question: What is a required feature for a SysML model to be syntactically conformant?
options: A. Use of SysML graphical notation
B. Compliance with the abstract syntax
C. Use of root namespaces
D. Presence of at least one package
E. Use of KerML textual notation

question: Which statements about packages are correct?
options: A. Packages can be nested
B. Packages can contain owned and unowned members
C. Packages cannot have aliases
D. Packages are required to filter all imports
E. Packages can own comments and documentation

question: What is the effect of deleting a namespace in SysML?
options: A. All owned members are deleted
B. Only the namespace is deleted, not its members
C. All non-owning memberships are deleted
D. Only aliases are deleted
E. Comments are never deleted

question: Which of the following is NOT true about SysML comments?
options: A. They can annotate multiple elements
B. They can be named
C. They must always annotate an element
D. They are always owned by namespaces
E. They can have bodies with markup

question: In textual notation, how is a documentation compartment represented?
options: A. By `doc /*...*/` inside an element
B. With the keyword `documentation`
C. As a graphical note
D. As a special import
E. As a protected alias

question: What is the default visibility of a package member?
options: A. private
B. public
C. protected
D. internal
E. package

question: Which of these are ways to extend SysML for a specific domain?
options: A. Using user-defined keywords
B. By creating Domain Libraries
C. By changing the abstract syntax
D. By modifying the KerML core directly
E. By using metadata annotations

question: Which statement about alias memberships is correct?
options: A. An alias is a non-owning membership
B. Alias names must be unique in the whole model
C. An element can have multiple alias memberships
D. Aliases cannot have visibility
E. Only packages can have aliases

question: What is true about comments declared within a namespace body?
options: A. They become owned members of the namespace
B. They cannot annotate the containing namespace
C. They must specify an `about` clause
D. They are automatically about the containing namespace if not specified
E. They always require a short name

question: Which is NOT a valid textual notation element in SysML?
options: A. part def
B. alias
C. connection
D. group
E. import

question: What is true about the concrete syntax of SysML?
options: A. It includes both textual and graphical notation
B. It is only for diagrams
C. Textual and graphical syntax are mapped to the same abstract syntax
D. Only graphical notation is required
E. The abstract syntax is part of the concrete syntax

question: Which of the following statements about owned elements is correct?
options: A. They are always deleted with their owner
B. They can exist without a namespace
C. They are also known as owned related elements
D. They are not considered part of the model
E. They must be visible outside the namespace

question: Which is a valid declaration for a recursive import?
options: A. import Namespace::**;
B. import Namespace::*;
C. import Namespace;
D. import *;
E. import Namespace::all;

question: Which of the following are true about the body of a comment?
options: A. It can contain markup
B. It is enclosed between /* and */
C. It can be omitted
D. It must reference another language
E. It can have multiple owners

question: What is a feature of a documentation comment that distinguishes it from a regular comment?
options: A. Always annotates its owning element
B. Can annotate multiple elements
C. Can be a namespace member
D. Written only in graphical notation
E. Cannot have a body

question: Which best describes an "element ID" in SysML?
options: A. Unique per element
B. Shown in textual notation
C. Can change after creation
D. Used for tool management
E. Can be omitted in the model

question: What is the result of declaring an alias in a package with the `private` keyword?
options: A. The alias is not visible outside the package
B. The alias is visible in all namespaces
C. The alias must have a body
D. It is not allowed
E. The alias is treated as protected

question: Which of the following are true for names and short names in SysML?
options: A. Names should be descriptive
B. Short names are delimited with `<` and `>`
C. Both can be omitted
D. Only one may be given
E. Names can include Unicode characters

question: Which is true about documentation comments in the context of a part definition?
options: A. They use the `doc` keyword
B. They are about the part definition
C. They require a name
D. They can include markup
E. They must be public

question: What does a membership relationship specify?
options: A. Name by which an element is known relative to a namespace
B. Whether an element is owned or not
C. Whether the element is visible outside the namespace
D. The deletion rules for the element
E. The graphical notation used

question: Which of these is NOT a purpose of the Systems Model Library?
options: A. Providing semantics for SysML language constructs
B. Supporting model-based systems engineering
C. Organizing user documentation
D. Extending the Kernel Library
E. Supplying reference models for domains

question: Which element is used to organize models in SysML?
options: A. Package
B. Attribute
C. Alias
D. Comment
E. Part

question: What are the two major forms of concrete syntax conformance in SysML?
options: A. Textual notation conformance
B. Abstract syntax conformance
C. Graphical notation conformance
D. Model interchange conformance
E. Domain library conformance

question: What is a valid visibility for a SysML alias?
options: A. public
B. protected
C. private
D. visible
E. global

question: What is the consequence of having no name or short name for an element?
options: A. It cannot be referenced in textual notation
B. It can only be referenced graphically
C. It must be deleted
D. It becomes a root element
E. It gains a default name

question: What can be included in a SysML package compartment?
options: A. Comments
B. Documentation
C. Parts
D. Attributes
E. All of the above

question: Which is true about documentation in the SysML textual notation?
options: A. It uses the `doc` keyword
B. It can be a compartment in an element
C. It is always about its owning element
D. It must be graphical
E. It can annotate multiple elements

question: What does the abstract syntax define in SysML?
options: A. The structure of models
B. The mapping from concrete syntax
C. The set of permissible model elements
D. The graphical notation
E. The serialization format

question: What is true about the graphical notation of SysML relationships?
options: A. Relationships are generally shown as lines
B. Additional shapes can be attached to relationship lines
C. Relationship symbols may have compartments
D. Only non-relationship elements use boxes
E. Graphical notation is optional in the standard
